docs.lead_paragraph: One night recently, when I was on call in the cardiac care unit at New York Presbyterian Hospital, I visited a patient who had been in the unit for nine days, recovering from a procedure to remove a clot in one of her coronary arteries. She was doing well, breathing on her own, with a normal blood pressure and regular heartbeat. I thought she was asleep.

headline.main: When a Stay in Intensive Care Unhinges the Mind

docs.abstract: Sandeep Jauhar article on the mysteries of ICU psychosis, which experts define as 'actute brain syndrome involving impaired intellectual functioning which occurs in patients who are being treated within a critical care unit'; says problem almost always vanishes when the patient leaves the intensive care unit; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Most lightning injuries occur in summer and the majority are suffered by golfers, fishermen, hikers and others enjoying warm weather sports. But according to a report issued by the Lightning Data Center in Denver, winter sports enthusiasts also are at risk, albeit, small. The report, which appears in the current British Journal of Sports Medicine, cites two instances in which lightning struck on the ski slopes.

headline.main: When Lightning Strikes on the Ski Slopes

docs.abstract: Lightning Data Center reports that while most lightning injuries affect golfers, fishermen, hikers and other people engaging in warm-weather sports, skiers and other winter sports enthusiasts are also at risk, albeit, small (S)
docs.snippet: Most lightning injuries occur in summer and the majority are suffered by golfers, fishermen, hikers and others enjoying warm weather sports. But according to a report issued by the Lightning Data Center in Denver, winter sports enthusiasts also are...

docs.lead_paragraph: Esoteric and highly technical, scientific journals have never been viewed as a hot publication market. In recent years, however, scientific journals have become big business, with large commercial publishers entering a scene once dominated by nonprofit scientific societies whose only goal was to disseminate scientific information. It is a change that many academics say has sent prices skyrocketing -- with some journals now costing libraries more than $15,000 a year. But scientists, whose universities are often unable to afford the very journals to which they are giving their research findings, are now teaming up with irate librarians to fight back. They are creating their own journals to compete with expensive commercial publications, and offering them at one-half to one-twentieth the price.

headline.main: Soaring Prices Spur a Revolt in Scientific Publishing

docs.abstract: Subscription rates for scientific and technical journals soar, and scientists respond by setting up their own low-cost publications; scientists argue that science is harmed when research can be shared only through journals costing $15,000 or more a year; commercial publishers, who now dominate a field that was once province of nonprofit societies, insist that their publications are high quality and remain a good value; photo of Dr Michael Rosenzweig and his wife, Carole, who publish Evolutionary Ecology Research from their home in Tucson, Ariz (M)
docs.snippet: Esoteric and highly technical, scientific journals have never been viewed as a hot publication market. In recent years, however, scientific journals have become big business, with large commercial publishers entering a scene once dominated by...

docs.lead_paragraph: In news that may be a bit frightening for anyone checking into a hospital, the Joint Commission on Accreditation of Healthcare Organizations has compiled statistics on major harmful events. The accreditation commission, an agency that certifies hospital quality, defines what it calls sentinel events as the unexpected occurrences that involve death or major permanent disabilities.

headline.main: Keeping Track, to Make Hospitals Safer

docs.abstract: Joint Commission on Accreditation of Healthcare Organizations compiles statistics on major harmful events that occur in hospitals; topping the list is patient suicide, followed by medication errors (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Shoehorning exercise into the schedule by doing small amounts several times a day improves fitness as much as a single daily workout of the same total time, according to research in the last few years. Now, a new report says that the multiple-dose plan also helps lower blood fats -- which are associated with heart disease -- as much as a one-shot session. In the study, published in a recent issue of Medicine and Science in Sports and Exercise, 18 men ate a high-fat meal, then exercised the next day.

headline.main: Exercising the Heart in Smaller Doses

docs.abstract: New study finds that shoehorning exercise into the schedule by doing small amounts several times a day helps lower blood fats as much as a single daily workout of the same total time; cartoon (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Exercisers are often confused about the best way to strengthen and tone the midriff. And for good reason: Experts cannot seem to agree either. Even the research is not definitive. For example, the biomechanics laboratory at Centinela Hospital Medical Center in Inglewood, Calif., completed a study this year comparing the effectiveness and safety of eight popular abdominal movements. To measure the amount of electrical activity -- and thus the force of muscular contraction -- researchers placed electrodes on each subject's three largest abdominal muscle groups -- the rectus abdominis, internal obliques and external obliques -- and on one hip flexor muscle. Of all the exercises, the crunch, or quarter sit-up, was shown to activate the greatest number of abdominal muscle fibers and the least number of hip flexor muscle fibers.

headline.main: Best Way to Build Abs? Who Knows?

docs.abstract: Experts disagree on the best way to strengthen and tone abdominal muscles, and even the research is not definitive; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Gonorrhea and syphilis remain serious problems in several of the nation's cities, though they have been nearly wiped out nationwide, Federal health officials said today. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention ranked the 20 cities with the highest rates for both sexually transmitted diseases. Baltimore led the nation in both gonorrhea and syphilis rates.

headline.main: 2 Sex Diseases High in 15 Cities, Low in U.S.

docs.abstract: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reports that gonorrhea and syphilis remain serious problems in several of nation's cities, though they have been nearly wiped out nationwide; Baltimore leads nation in both gonorrhea and syphilis rates; CDC also lists states reporting the highest levels of chlamydia among young women (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Amid the recent blitz of scientific studies on the effectiveness of herbal treatments, Dr. Alan M. Dattner, a Westchester County dermatologist, stepped back to take a look at several herbal preparations that have sometimes been used to treat common dermatological problems. In the November issue of Archives of Dermatology, he and his co-author, Dr. Donald J. Brown, a New Jersey-based naturopathic physician and editor of The Quarterly Review of Natural Medicine, noted that many doctors offered both prescription medicines and herbal preparations to their patients.

headline.main: With Herbs, a 'Fuller Palette' for Skin Care

docs.abstract: Dr Alan M Dattner, dermatologist, and Dr Donald J Brown, naturopathic physician, write a paper on what is known about herbal preparations for treatment of common skin problems, including dermatitis, psoriasis and herpes simplex labialis; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Feline Transplants Q. Can cats have organ transplants? A. Yes, in some cases. The School of Veterinary Medicine at the University of California at Davis does about 30 kidney transplants a year for cats, at a cost of $3,000 to $4,000. Dr. Clare R. Gregory, a veterinarian who is a professor in the department of surgery and radiological sciences, said there were no other transplant programs for dogs or cats, though there was initial research on partial liver transplants. Because there is no organ procurement program for animals, he explained, veterinarians have to use live donors that can survive either donation of one of two organs or partial organ transplants.
docs.abstract: NASA astronauts are undergoing training for the many space walks they will have to take to assemble international space station, the ultimate high-beam construction project; space station and earlier American designs have been criticized for requiring too many space walks to build and maintain; critics say so many space walks not only increase risks to crews but also divert time from scientific work aboard station; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: New research is challenging the medical textbook view of osteoporosis as largely a women's disease linked to the singularly female experience of menopause. It now seems that osteoporosis is more prevalent in men than previously thought and that, although men do not go through menopause, the main cause of the degenerative bone disorder is the same in men and women: an age-related drop in estrogen. Several recent studies show that men's levels of this sex hormone decline with age and that the decline leads to a loss of bone mass, the signature symptom of osteoporosis. Some of these studies were presented last week at a meeting of the American Society for Bone and Mineral Research and the International Bone and Mineral Society in San Francisco.

headline.main: Weak Bones Among Men Are Linked To Estrogen

docs.abstract: Research finds that osteoporosis is more prevalent in men than previously thought and that, as with women, it is due to age-related drop in estrogen; osteoporosis in men has heretofore been attributed to abnormally low levels of testosterone (M)
